summary: Andrew Rannells On 'Fumbling Toward' Adulthood And Broadway Fame
title: Andrew Rannells On 'Fumbling Toward' Adulthood And Broadway Fame
excerpt: Andrew Rannells has come a long way from Omaha, which he left in the late '90s to follow his dream of becoming a Broadway star in New York City. His new book, "Too Much Is Not Enough: A Memoir of Fumbling Toward Adulthood" tells the story of his early years there. He tells Sam about learning his dad died on a half-hearted date, getting drunk in piano bars with his best friend, Zuzanna, and how a failed audition for Rosie O'Donnell might have changed the course of his career.
description:
Sam Sanders: Are there ever roles — gay roles — you will not take because you’re worried about what they model for young gay people?

Andrew Rannells: Well, I talk a little about it in the book that very early in my career I did basically this large-scale children’s production of a show called Pokemon Live. The character I played was one of the villains and he was a very, sort of, over-the-top fop in this story, and it required doing what I consider to be a very gross generalization and depiction of a gay person. It was so ridiculous, and so stereotypical.

Sam: What was the worst part of that caricature?

Andrew: Seeing kids watch it. Because I was getting laughs for doing things that I wasn’t proud of. And knowing there were kids in the audience — and just because of the way the world works, there’s gonna be a bunch of gay ones out there — and they thought somehow, or that if they did think about it, that that’s how gay people have to act to be funny. 

And that was really hard. And I hated myself for being in a position where I felt like I had to take that job because I needed the money, and I was so humiliated — not just because it was Pokemon Live but that I was playing this gay clown in Pokemon Live.

And knowing there were kids in the audience — and just because of the way the world works, there’s gonna be a bunch of gay ones out there — and they thought somehow, or that if they did think about it, that that’s how gay people have to act to be funny. 

And that was really hard. And I hated myself for being in a position where I felt like I had to take that job because I needed the money, and I was so humiliated — not just because it was Pokemon Live but that I was playing this gay clown in Pokemon Live.

Andrew: Seeing kids watch it. Because I was getting laughs for doing things that I wasn’t proud of. blog.name: tigerlover16-uk
blog.title: Tiger Lover 16-UK
blog.description: Jack Humphreys, Age 24, From Wales. I'm a Christian, animal lover, an animation fan and a gigantic nerd. Fan of Spider-man, Dragon Ball, DC and Marvel Comics, MLP, Harry Potter and a variety of other shows, movies, comics and books. I'm just here to have fun, do some good and talk about the things i like (And sometimes the stuff I don't).

summary: You know I was meh on Meltan for a while. I thought it was fine, but not all that interesting or unique looking compared to a...
body:
You know I was meh on Meltan for a while. I thought it was fine, but not all that interesting or unique looking compared to a lot of mythical Pokémon.

The anime completely sold me on the little nut boys though. It’s amazing how you can make little blobs of liquid metal with hexagonal nut for a head so utterly adorable.

reblog.comment:
